title: Exploring the formation mechanism of ferulic acid/hydroxypropyl‐β‐cyclodextrin inclusion complex: spectral analyses and computer simulation
content:
Abstract

BACKGROUND

The biological functions of ferulic acid (FA) have garnered significant interest, but its limited solubility and stability have led to low bioavailability. Hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD), with its distinctive hollow structure, offers the potential for encapsulating hydrophobic molecules. Therefore, the formation of an inclusion complex between FA and HP-β-CD may serve as a viable approach to address the inherent limitations of FA. To investigate the underlying mechanism of FA/HP-β-CD inclusion complex formation, a combination of spectral analyses and computer simulation was employed.

RESULTS

The disappearance of the characteristic peaks of FA in FT-IR and XRD provided confirmation of the formation of an inclusion complex between FA and HP-β-CD. Furthermore, the TG-DTG studies demonstrated that the thermal stability of FA was enhanced due to the encapsulation of FA within HP-β-CD. Additionally, molecular dynamics simulation provided evidence that FA successfully penetrated the HP-β-CD cavity, primarily driven by van der Waals interactions. The formation of the complex resulted in more compact HP-β-CD structures. Furthermore, the bioavailability of FA was strengthened through the formation of inclusion complexes with HP-β-CD.

CONCLUSIONS

The findings of this study have contributed to a deeper understanding of the interactions between FA and HP-β-CD, potentially aiding in the advancement of a delivery system for FA and enhancing the bioavailability of insoluble active components.
